F.cTs.-A single mercantile house, on Long
wharf. Boston, has sold. since the first Of January
last, Muy-seuen Thousand barrels of Genaessce
flour of which less than 500 barrels have been dis
passed Of stwise the remainder has been sold to
country traders and chiefly to those in the manu-.
featuring villages.


Another house has paid, since the first of April,
one hundred and fifty thousand dollars for Americma
wool, purchased of farmers and wool growers be.
longing to the New England states and New York,
and sold out again to the manufacturers of New
England.


The Boston and Canton Factory company i'm.
ported, during five months preceding the first Of
May last, one million Of pounds of Smyrna wool
all of which is used in its own factory, in the manu-
acture of what is called negro cloths.
Is it possible that our manufacturing establish
ments can be detrimental to commerce and asricul-
ture, when a single establishment imports wool
enough in five months to freight three or four ships
TO say nothing of other articles necessarily used in
the manufacture of the wool , when single dealer
in American wool pays, in the same time the farm.
ers 81 O,OOO and another individual receives from
another portion of farmers and sells off to the coun-
try traders -four enough to make its first owners
rich, if not independent
From The Boston Courier.

produce for return--whicb OF any description, will
not place at current prices more than IS to G3 cents
per dollar in the United States on cost here.


We, consequently are not in want of imports of
any kind. The most abundant in our line, are Flour
and Salt Provisions. OF Flour there are about
$4,000 bbls. on hand. Any quotations would be
nominal. We do not sell at the rate bf 5000 bbls.
per month, and the markets at the south, offer no
relief to US, although some cargoes must go on. as
there is chance whatever of doing any thing here.
The Phoenix will go to Rio Grand, with 800 bbls.
several other cargoes are daily looked for from
the U. States I'VE possessed with the most gloo
my anticipation the subject of politics. as well
as commerce.

to the command Of all the land and naval forces, in
the Soulh.'

g never heard that Gen. Jackson was in the bah;t
Of acting in the wild, eccentric manner that Mr.

This writer has made further discovery-tb,4
Mr.. Buchanan, in every instance. has foraotpn
those parts OF the conversation which are tho nnt
important in the statement of Gen. jackson Al
this obyousness he quotes proof that those nonts
were made in the conversation. and that Mr. Bucb-
anan's memory became indistinct in relation 10 them
because he would not compromise his own ebars,..

Finally, 'Poug hman" comes to the conclusion

to convict a wretch arragnedfor murder "PIouph.

racter of legal evidence. lie should have left that

We do not think that some Of the most zeams
advocates of Gen. Jackson will thank 6 sP!oughmann
for turning up the very roots of their propositions n
the way he has done, nor will we believe that Mr.
Buchanan will be much pleased with having this
plough share driven into his character.

We learn by the Boston Palladium of Friday, that
Che brig Nymph has arrived there from St. SALIVA
dor, bringing letters, papers, &c. TO August lS The
British vessels Ganges, seventy one. and Huron,
seventeen, had arrived there from Rio Janeiro.
The latter carried the treaty to Buenos Ayres and
brought back the rejection.


Erract of letter receiped at Bahia from RIO Janeiro


dated Juiy 81.


The arrival ofthe Huron, from Buenos Ayres, on
Che 9th inst, giving intelligence Of the rejection of
the terms proposed to that government, and conse-
quently has disappointed all our hopes of peace ;
which, indeed, no reasonable NAH could have doubt
ed of, had the terms been made public They SEEM
those OF an arbitrary conqueror to detected and
helpless people, place, IN strong light, the con-
tempt OF this government Tor ether nations, and
shew AN imbeciity or ignorance on the part of this
Ministry, and that Of Mr.. Gordon the British Minis
try, under whose patronage they were rendered
quite unlocked for. The government and people
OF b. A. rejected them with indignation, and change
OF Administration there immediately took place
Don Manuel Garcia, it is said, was obliged to hide
himself from popular fury, and Rivatlava resigned
the Presidency, which it is supposed, will brn!
about an union OF The provinces. We may expect
vigorous prosecution of the war on their part an,
prlvateers will, we apprchend, entirely dostro
the coasting trade. What course this court vii
pursue. we know not but under their circum
stances one would suppose they would inmediatel
accept the best terms they could get, and restor
Teace to the nation This, however, appears il,
not to be thought of, and there is talk of pushir
onward further equipment Of troops. which wi
probably only tend to exhaust the resourcas of II
Government, without being sufficiently numerous
affective to turn the tide of fortune now se;,g !;
strongly against them. The effect Of the state


.hings in our market is most dscouraging There
sso security in states. Our Bank Paper has dcnr
ais;ed b0 per cent, and there is an absolute want
LATEST FROM BRAZIL.

Gen. Jackson and the Secretary Of the Navy--
The correspondence between these eminent citizens
has not yet been brought to light, though from oc
casonal hints in the public papers, perceive thu.
there is yet possibility of the Public's being favor
ed with it. A writer in the National Journal, VIII"
seems to know very well what he is about says thai
copy of this correspondence was sent by Gen. Jact
son, as long ago in April last, to supporter a.
his at Fredericksburg, and is read to individuals W
From, the National htelKgencer.

August27.


We had an administration meeting here on the
goth. About 500 people attended; and it is now
ascertaned that there are only 40 or SO Jackson
ties in the county consequently the Adams tucked
will obtain a majority of about 450 votes. All the
French and creoes together with four iifths Of the
American population in the parishes of St. Mary.
|St. Martins, and Lafayette, are decidedly with the
administration. Be assured Connecticut itselts nor
more certain for Adams than Louisiana.


Extract of a letter from Cincinnati. dated Sep. IT,
8 Ohio will 20 almost unanimous for the admins.
Itraton. Indeed, believe we shall have majority
in Cincinnati, the very hot-bed of Jacksonsm IN
this State.


We had an administration meeting yesterday az
the Circus. 1t was the largest and most respectable
meeting every held IN this city-Major William
Rufin, late high sheriff of this county, was called
to the chair, and Benjamin Drake, ESQ. and Smith
Crossin Esq were appointed secretaries. General
Harrison, our Senator in Congress, delivered avery
able and eloquent address TO the meeting.


The meeting was also addressed by Samuel W.
Davies, Esq. Charles Hammond, Esq. and many
other of our old and respectable citizens The
General dwelt long on the policy and the measures
| of the existing government-spoke freely of the
woolen's bill-explalned why it was rejected, Sc
Sc 1t was indeed the most powerful address ever
heard from him. This meeting will help our cause
very much. The district has always been consider
ed Jackson district but we have now strong hopes
of beating them in our State election which takes
place on the first Tuesday Of October.
". Y. paper.

THE PRESIDENTIAL QUESTION.
Extract of letter dated Opelousas, Louisiana

writer in the Richmond Enquirer, adopting the
signature of Ploughman," has amused himself
with making series of observations on MIR. Bucba-
mans letter. He ridicules the attempt which has
been made by some of the opposition papers, (the
Telegraph acting as bell-weather.) "to reconcile
the statement Of MIR. Buchanan with that of Gen.
jackson there is discrepancy between them
(says he) that is irreconcable." We call on the
Editor Of the New York Evening Post, by all his
reputation for ability, by all his love of chiyary, by
all his hope Of political salvation, to come forward
and defend his own revised opinions and not to
suffer himself to be thus pricked by hobnail.'
$ Poughman'' charges Mr.. Buchanan with being
g uncandd'' and displaying too much anxiety t6
defend his own reputation yet he again tells US
that MIR. Buchanan has reputation to defend, fol
that 6 ,,iae-tenhs of the American people were to
tally ignorant of his existence, until his recent col
lision with General ]. :" and again, that he is 81


man, whose political pre-eminence is perfect ephe


meron; !" adding, for the information of the friend
of General Jackson, that ephemeron is, sa thin


Of Yesterday" All this is very complimentary t


Mr.. Buchanan.


: Waxing warmer as he proceeds, g ploughman
From Tie National Journal.

BRITIsH Policy. 1t is well known principle of
policy in the British Cabinet that in all their neao-
ciationsin all their foreign measures, they keep
strict eye to the advancement of their trade and
manufactures. This view has characterised their
national conduct for series of ages The late ne
gocatlons for the pacfcatlon of Greece will not be
found an exception 1t is already stated in the En-
sish papers, that in the event of refusal on the part
OF the Dvan to acquiese in the terms proposed for
the settlement OF Greece, the powers intend to estab
Iish consuls Or commercial agents in the latter
country. Suspicious also awake that the recent
detection Of Egypt from the cause of the Porte has
not been accomplished without the knowledge oi
the new allies The ultimate object of England il


taking the part she has done in favor of the classical


land. cannot he referred altogether her moral senst
OF the wrongs of Greece the insults of the Porte
! Within the last lew years very singular spirit O
industry and enterprise has been awakened in somt
OF the ancient countries bordering on the Medterane
an. Greece and Egypt SO famous in the annals D
antiquity, have sown symptoms of renovation


The spirit Of Liberty has bestrred itself in the for


mer and the genius OF industry, has been revived il


the latter. Egypt may again become the sranar
lot tine world and Greece very considerable mar


time power in the East. The cotton plant has bee


introduced into the country of the Nile with til
most astonishing success. The leading object {
: England may well therefore be divided. Why di
she recognize the independence of the South Amer
can Republics? Because they presented marke
t for her manufactures, A similar answer will ami
G elsewhere.
From, the National .4duocate.

Hayti We learn by recent arrival at New
York, that the British Agent at Hayti. MIR. Ken
sic was about to quit the Island, and return to Great
Britain. This event may be considered as quite
important among the signs Of the times in that
try. The probability is, that the British Agent has
found the government so completely abandoned to
French influence, that nothing beneficial by way OF
commercial arrangement could be effected; and
that the continuance Of peace. order and security
in the Island, was precarious. that it was not ad
visable for him to remain. There appears to be
good ground for suspectng that Bower has engaged
in systematic design TO reduce to slavery or to ex.
terminate the blacks and that civil war between
them and the mutut0es, French party, will at nc
distant day, be waged with more than former fury.
| If Boyer and the mulattoes, aided by the French
should triumph, the result will probably be, that the
Island 10 all practical purposes will continue
French colony. Accounts have recently been re
ceived that the blacks were transporting provisions
to the mountains. u measure strongly indicative o
approaching troubles.
BosToN, SEPTEMBER, 81.

PARLIAMENTARY CHARACTERS.-ih ne new Lord
Chancellor is person Of very striking figure and
counteDance. He seems exceedingly at his ease on
the woosack | heard him one occasion retort
on Lord Elenborough with as much asperty Of tone
and manner as have ever witnessed on triiling
occasion


The duke Of Wellington is fdgetty and talkative
person while their ordships are in deIiberation.-H
is perpetually shifting his position, and whispering
to the person who happens to sit nexthm.


Lord Goderlch is person whose speech is better
to the sight, Or paper than to the ear. The re-
verse. probably. may be said Of Lords Dudley and
Ward i; there is great precision. smoothiees ahd
force, in what he delivers. Lord LansdoWn. how
ever, appears to be the best speaker in the upper
house. He is one of the best sentence makers
ever heard and what he does in this way is done
with amazing facility. A writer. who is particular
about his periods and lastidious in the co'iocuton
of words especially when the ideas to be expressed
have good deal Of complexi,y, knows well the uni
ty of pause, and an opportunity for emendaton
The greatest niceties of phrase, and elcitles OF ar
rangement, exhibited by him off hand, and with
out the least show of hesitation effort. When
say in the upper house," mean, of course in the
active discharge of its duties. | refer only to the
members whose voices are familiar to the ears OF
those who hear its debates. | can scarcely yet re-
gard Lord Plunket OF the band OF the :" Lords
Temporal" He isas yet non-enty IN their sphere
but when he thinks proper to exercise his energies,



his station master of eocutlon, will, n course,
be what it was in the region from which he has as
cended--that is, it will place him above all compe-
tition and rivalry.


Peel looks yet very young but increased fullness
of person and gravity of countenance, mark in some
measure the progress of time. | should suppose he
is now about 40. for he made his maiden speech III
favor Of the Walcheren expedition in lS09 and he
must have been 81 at that time. His appearance
is that Of SMOOTH self satisfied man OF 40.
who has husbanded his health, and with whom the
world in general has thrven. He is said to be fond
Of the relaxation and quiet Of domestic life, and
that he does not make an empty boast when he says
that he has ratherfled from than been the pursner d
Office 1t would not probably be easy to estimate
how much he owes of the character he has for dis
interestedness and integrity to his tendency Of his
feelings and habits. He is Indifferent to office pro
bably because he is careful of his health. is font
OF his wife, or is rich, or has poor relations t.
provide for, or has got great deal OF station and
some fame by accident, and does not wish to hazard
the loss of any portion of them in official squad
bes or from any other cause equally defectable to
self. Probably his predictions to be traced to
success more strongly marking the magnanlmlty oil
his character but be this as it may, it is shrewdy
supected that, with the colleagues he had. he never
would have been able to introduce the little in
novatlon he has attempted in the criminal laws. q
he was not ready at all times to say, that he did moi
want office, and that he would be thankful to be c
,eved from its solicitude. There is certainly some
thng very imposing in an apparent contempt of au
thorlty and pef in contention for which, the worle
as kept in such agitation aud turmoil. Would tina
all public men shared in the sentiment, or could
successfully affect to do so ! | could lay my hnge
upon one great man who, by the mere show Of til,
dlslnterestedness of which the entire Peel family ar,
so boasted, could, in all human Likelihood, on NOR
occasions than one. have given freedom to a who'll
A q "a
pacity, it is, think, manltestly on the decline il
the House. Fortune intended high destiny 70
him-nature very humble one. Probably the iickl
goddess has now abandoned him to his own energe
and these, as think is already evident cannot, al
ter the lapse of very little time, keep him abov
the level of the fourth or fifth class even OF the mer
debaters Ne,0 York Times.
From d London Correspondent.

by vessel arrived at this port from NIarseilles,
we have received ii series of letters from Greece,
from Gen. Jarvis and DR.. Howe. We have not yet
had leisure TO peruse them all ; but that from the
laergentleman is Of deep interest, and gives Wv
I'D description Of the present state Of that distracted
country. The following postscript is dated Poros,
July 18th.


"P. s. The ship Six Brothers arriving at Ma
poll from New York, thought it my duty to advise
her rot 10 remain, as trouble was brewing and |
came here in her. This moment letters from Ma
poll inform that open war has broken out in the
place between Gryas, commander OF the upper cas-
IT,, anil Fontoumaris, commanding the lower. Gri-
vas is bombarding the place men, women and
children are killed and wounded every hour and
the English commander lying there has been obliged
to threaten in order to save the remaining families
the houses and shops are puudered a horrd
scene of confusion is going on-I go there in day
or two, to try TO remove the Hospital, and shall
write you.'' NJ Y. Com. .adv
FROM GREECE

Quick woRK.-We understand that the letter
from Jackson to Owens, in which be ISLANDERS the
living and the dead, was sent BY express from Ten
nessee to Owens in kentucky-who sentit by ex.
press to printer hundred miles distant. 1t was
then printed in handbs, and circulated by ex-
press. Although dated the 25th of July, and first
printed nigh 200 mile. from Robertson's Springs,
where it was written. it was sent to every County
in the state--at any rate to every Congressional
Dstrct--before the election. which commenced the
first Monday in August Quere-Who paid the ex.
peuse Ovens is notoriously bankrupt.


jackson wrote another electoneering letter to II.
Daniel, which was used in his stump speeches.
We should like To see that letter also printed
Every thing Old Hickory writes ought to go down
to posteri,y. AS they say in Tennessee, he ha'
ne1er placed lis name in block and ghae, that 1t de-
not elcuote him IN The eyes Of has cosonrymn.v Vide
Nashville Republican, Sept a. The letter to Da
mel of course i. splendid production, for it no
only elevated the Generals but his correspondent
too 1t elected him to Congress BY all means lie
us have the letter if sent to US in manuscript W.
will do our best to correct the orthography and syn
tax.-Kentucky Reporter.
DE WITT CLINTON.

Mrs. Hemana, the celebrated poetcss. having
been invited by the proprietors of the Philadelphia
Ladies Album, to take charge of that periodical
publication, with salary Of fifteen hundred dollars
per annum, has returned the following answer:
..RHi DON, ST. AsApii, 14th Aug. 1897.


" Sif,---l heg to acknowledge with thanks the ia

your Of your very oblisns letter. and request you to
inform your American friend, that am gratefully
sensible Of the compliment paid me by the offer you
have transmitted, but that the prospects 1T holds
forth, however tlattering, would not counterbaance
the Inconvenience attendant on leaving my own
country.


81 am, sir, your obliged servant,


SigneL FELICIA IlEMANS."

The following proclamation removing Eli Bruce,
the sheriff of Niagara county, has been issued by
Governor Clinton Mr.. Bruce was one OF the per-
sons concerned in the abduction of Morgan This
exercise of power on the part of the Governor will
be commended by every one


BY DE WI1TJLLV1ONG Governor Of The Stale Of


Ne,c- FORK.


Whereas Eli Bruce, sheriff of the county of Mia
CARA. has been charged before with violation u
his duties good citizen, and faithful officer, in
being concerned in the abduction of William Nor
gan, and has been heard in his defence: And where
as, in the investigation Of the said accusation, it ap
peared thatit was completely in the power Of the
And whereas, order to afford him that opportunity,
decision on the complaint has been suspended for
an ample time, and he has given no explanation OF
his conduct: And whereas it appears that at re-
cent trial at Canandaigua of certain persons charged
with the said abduction, the said Eli Bruce, when
called OH witness, refused to testify several
material points, OH the ground Of determination ;
from all of which, am persuaded that he was par
tcipant in the said abduction, and thereby has rem
dered himself unworthy Of the official station which
he at present occupies do therefore, pursuant to
the powers vested in me by the constitution of this
state remove the said Eli Bruce from the office Of
sheriff Of the county of Niagara
In witness whereof | have hereunto set my
H.. s. hand and the privy seal of the state, at the
city OF Albany, this 26Ih day of September,
Ammo Dumini, 1927.

Extract o leffer from gentleman n RIO Janslro,


doted a3d Of July, 1927.


"Ihe Buenos Ayres privateers come almost to
the mouth Of the harbour, and make many captures.
When within days sail of this port, the brig Leo
pard, of New York, for st. GATHERINGS bound here,
was brought to by pryateer and a Brazilian
gentleman passenger taken from her the privateer
formerly belonged to Baltimore, and was then call
ed the Beauty" Four or five days since, one O
these daring fellows hailed French frigate, anc
obtaining rather rough answer Immediately haul
ed athwart her (the irigate's) stern, and poured .
full broad side of grapesho into her wounded the
Commodore in the leg, besides killing two or three
men. have been informed that since his arrival
the commodore has had his leg amputated."

Extract Of letter from gentleman IN Rio Jansiro,


dated 23d Of JNlu. 1927.

We understand that letters have been received
from General ATKINSON, dated on the Cd of Sepem.
ber. The General had with five hundred men. as
cended eighty miles up the Ouiscensin, on his way
to the Portage, and had been joined the preceding
evening by General DoDGE, with one hundred and
thirty Galena volunteers, mounted men. AT the
Portage, General ATKINSON would be met by Ma.
ior WHISTLER, with the detachment from Green
Bay, and would then hay collected force of one
thousand men, ready to move aa circumstances di.
rect. No hostile Indians had been met with, and
the General, at the date of his last letter. was still Of
opinion that the Wnnebagoes would give up the Of.
tenders agreeably to the demand which had been
made upon them.


A runor had reached BeIeville, in Illinois, thas
an attack had been made by the Indians upon the
settlers at the Lead Mines on Fever river, but by
the direct accounts which we have from ST. Louis,
to the 9Th ultimo, it proves to be entirely unfound
led


On Tuesday last. an address was delivered before
the Wing and Cliosophical societies of Princeton
College, in the presence of the faculty the trustees,
land large assemblage of citizens, by Theodore
Frelinshuysen, Esq. Attorney General of New.
Jersey.


| The veteran Commodore John Rodgers has been
appointed Commissioner Of the Navy. The Board
ls now mplete-consisting of Commodore Rodgers,


President, and Commodores Tin.ey and Warning


ton.


On Wednesday last, was the annual commence.


ment of the college at Princeton. n. J. vast
crowd Of citizens and strangers assembled, among


whom was Samuel l.. Southard Esq, Secretary Of


the U. S. Navy. who is now on a visit to his frends


in this state. The performances were highly crcti.
table to chose concerned.
From the National Intelkgencey.

ported, during five months preceding the first Of

all of which is used in its own factory, in the manu-
acture of what is called negro cloths.
Is it possible that our manufacturing establish

enough in five months to freight three or four ships
TO say nothing of other articles necessarily used in
the manufacture of the wool , when single dealer

another portion of farmers and sells off to the coun-
try traders -four enough to make its first owners
rich, if not independent

produce for return--whicb OF any description, will
not place at current prices more than IS to G3 cents
per dollar in the United States on cost here.


We, consequently are not in want of imports of

per month, and the markets at the south, offer no

full articles.article:
We learn by the Boston Palladium of Friday, that

dor, bringing letters, papers, &c. TO August lS The

The latter carried the treaty to Buenos Ayres and
brought back the rejection.


Erract of letter receiped at Bahia from RIO Janeiro


dated Juiy 81.


The arrival ofthe Huron, from Buenos Ayres, on
Che 9th inst, giving intelligence Of the rejection of
the terms proposed to that government, and conse-
quently has disappointed all our hopes of peace ;
which, indeed, no reasonable NAH could have doubt
ed of, had the terms been made public They SEEM
those OF an arbitrary conqueror to detected and
helpless people, place, IN strong light, the con-
tempt OF this government Tor ether nations, and
shew AN imbeciity or ignorance on the part of this
Ministry, and that Of Mr.. Gordon the British Minis
try, under whose patronage they were rendered
quite unlocked for. The government and people
OF b. A. rejected them with indignation, and change
OF Administration there immediately took place
Don Manuel Garcia, it is said, was obliged to hide
himself from popular fury, and Rivatlava resigned
the Presidency, which it is supposed, will brn!
about an union OF The provinces. We may expect
vigorous prosecution of the war on their part an,
prlvateers will, we apprchend, entirely dostro
the coasting trade. What course this court vii
pursue. we know not but under their circum
stances one would suppose they would inmediatel
accept the best terms they could get, and restor
Teace to the nation This, however, appears il,
not to be thought of, and there is talk of pushir
onward further equipment Of troops. which wi
probably only tend to exhaust the resourcas of II
Government, without being sufficiently numerous
affective to turn the tide of fortune now se;,g !;
strongly against them. The effect Of the state


.hings in our market is most dscouraging There
sso security in states. Our Bank Paper has dcnr
ais;ed b0 per cent, and there is an absolute want

full articles.headline: From, the National htelKgencer.
full articles.article:
Gen. Jackson and the Secretary Of the Navy--
The correspondence between these eminent citizens
has not yet been brought to light, though from oc
casonal hints in the public papers, perceive thu.
there is yet possibility of the Public's being favor
ed with it. A writer in the National Journal, VIII"
seems to know very well what he is about says thai
copy of this correspondence was sent by Gen. Jact
son, as long ago in April last, to supporter a.
his at Fredericksburg, and is read to individuals W

full articles.headline:
THE PRESIDENTIAL QUESTION.
Extract of letter dated Opelousas, Louisiana
full articles.article:
August27.


We had an administration meeting here on the
goth. About 500 people attended; and it is now
ascertaned that there are only 40 or SO Jackson
ties in the county consequently the Adams tucked
will obtain a majority of about 450 votes. All the
French and creoes together with four iifths Of the
American population in the parishes of St. Mary.
|St. Martins, and Lafayette, are decidedly with the
administration. Be assured Connecticut itselts nor
more certain for Adams than Louisiana.


Extract of a letter from Cincinnati. dated Sep. IT,
8 Ohio will 20 almost unanimous for the admins.
Itraton. Indeed, believe we shall have majority
in Cincinnati, the very hot-bed of Jacksonsm IN
this State.


We had an administration meeting yesterday az
the Circus. 1t was the largest and most respectable
meeting every held IN this city-Major William
Rufin, late high sheriff of this county, was called
to the chair, and Benjamin Drake, ESQ. and Smith
Crossin Esq were appointed secretaries. General
Harrison, our Senator in Congress, delivered avery
able and eloquent address TO the meeting.


The meeting was also addressed by Samuel W.
Davies, Esq. Charles Hammond, Esq. and many
other of our old and respectable citizens The
General dwelt long on the policy and the measures
| of the existing government-spoke freely of the
woolen's bill-explalned why it was rejected, Sc
Sc 1t was indeed the most powerful address ever
heard from him. This meeting will help our cause
very much. The district has always been consider
ed Jackson district but we have now strong hopes
of beating them in our State election which takes
place on the first Tuesday Of October.
". Y. paper.

full articles.headline: From Tie National Journal.
full articles.article:
writer in the Richmond Enquirer, adopting the
signature of Ploughman," has amused himself
with making series of observations on MIR. Bucba-
mans letter. He ridicules the attempt which has
been made by some of the opposition papers, (the
Telegraph acting as bell-weather.) "to reconcile
the statement Of MIR. Buchanan with that of Gen.
jackson there is discrepancy between them
(says he) that is irreconcable." We call on the
Editor Of the New York Evening Post, by all his
reputation for ability, by all his love of chiyary, by
all his hope Of political salvation, to come forward
and defend his own revised opinions and not to
suffer himself to be thus pricked by hobnail.'
$ Poughman'' charges Mr.. Buchanan with being
g uncandd'' and displaying too much anxiety t6
defend his own reputation yet he again tells US
that MIR. Buchanan has reputation to defend, fol
that 6 ,,iae-tenhs of the American people were to
tally ignorant of his existence, until his recent col
lision with General ]. :" and again, that he is 81


man, whose political pre-eminence is perfect ephe


meron; !" adding, for the information of the friend
of General Jackson, that ephemeron is, sa thin


Of Yesterday" All this is very complimentary t


Mr.. Buchanan.


: Waxing warmer as he proceeds, g ploughman

full articles.headline: From, the National .4duocate.
full articles.article:
BRITIsH Policy. 1t is well known principle of
policy in the British Cabinet that in all their neao-
ciationsin all their foreign measures, they keep
strict eye to the advancement of their trade and
manufactures. This view has characterised their
national conduct for series of ages The late ne
gocatlons for the pacfcatlon of Greece will not be
found an exception 1t is already stated in the En-
sish papers, that in the event of refusal on the part
OF the Dvan to acquiese in the terms proposed for
the settlement OF Greece, the powers intend to estab
Iish consuls Or commercial agents in the latter
country. Suspicious also awake that the recent
detection Of Egypt from the cause of the Porte has
not been accomplished without the knowledge oi
the new allies The ultimate object of England il


taking the part she has done in favor of the classical


land. cannot he referred altogether her moral senst
OF the wrongs of Greece the insults of the Porte
! Within the last lew years very singular spirit O
industry and enterprise has been awakened in somt
OF the ancient countries bordering on the Medterane
an. Greece and Egypt SO famous in the annals D
antiquity, have sown symptoms of renovation


The spirit Of Liberty has bestrred itself in the for


mer and the genius OF industry, has been revived il


the latter. Egypt may again become the sranar
lot tine world and Greece very considerable mar


time power in the East. The cotton plant has bee


introduced into the country of the Nile with til
most astonishing success. The leading object {
: England may well therefore be divided. Why di
she recognize the independence of the South Amer
can Republics? Because they presented marke
t for her manufactures, A similar answer will ami
G elsewhere.

full articles.headline: BosToN, SEPTEMBER, 81.
full articles.article:
Hayti We learn by recent arrival at New
York, that the British Agent at Hayti. MIR. Ken
sic was about to quit the Island, and return to Great
Britain. This event may be considered as quite
important among the signs Of the times in that
try. The probability is, that the British Agent has
found the government so completely abandoned to
French influence, that nothing beneficial by way OF
commercial arrangement could be effected; and
that the continuance Of peace. order and security
in the Island, was precarious. that it was not ad
visable for him to remain. There appears to be
good ground for suspectng that Bower has engaged
in systematic design TO reduce to slavery or to ex.
terminate the blacks and that civil war between
them and the mutut0es, French party, will at nc
distant day, be waged with more than former fury.
| If Boyer and the mulattoes, aided by the French
should triumph, the result will probably be, that the
Island 10 all practical purposes will continue
French colony. Accounts have recently been re
ceived that the blacks were transporting provisions
to the mountains. u measure strongly indicative o
approaching troubles.

full articles.headline: From d London Correspondent.
full articles.article:
PARLIAMENTARY CHARACTERS.-ih ne new Lord
Chancellor is person Of very striking figure and
counteDance. He seems exceedingly at his ease on
the woosack | heard him one occasion retort
on Lord Elenborough with as much asperty Of tone
and manner as have ever witnessed on triiling
occasion


The duke Of Wellington is fdgetty and talkative
person while their ordships are in deIiberation.-H
is perpetually shifting his position, and whispering
to the person who happens to sit nexthm.


Lord Goderlch is person whose speech is better
to the sight, Or paper than to the ear. The re-
verse. probably. may be said Of Lords Dudley and
Ward i; there is great precision. smoothiees ahd
force, in what he delivers. Lord LansdoWn. how
ever, appears to be the best speaker in the upper
house. He is one of the best sentence makers
ever heard and what he does in this way is done
with amazing facility. A writer. who is particular
about his periods and lastidious in the co'iocuton
of words especially when the ideas to be expressed
have good deal Of complexi,y, knows well the uni
ty of pause, and an opportunity for emendaton
The greatest niceties of phrase, and elcitles OF ar
rangement, exhibited by him off hand, and with
out the least show of hesitation effort. When
say in the upper house," mean, of course in the
active discharge of its duties. | refer only to the
members whose voices are familiar to the ears OF
those who hear its debates. | can scarcely yet re-
gard Lord Plunket OF the band OF the :" Lords
Temporal" He isas yet non-enty IN their sphere
but when he thinks proper to exercise his energies,



his station master of eocutlon, will, n course,
be what it was in the region from which he has as
cended--that is, it will place him above all compe-
tition and rivalry.


Peel looks yet very young but increased fullness
of person and gravity of countenance, mark in some
measure the progress of time. | should suppose he
is now about 40. for he made his maiden speech III
favor Of the Walcheren expedition in lS09 and he
must have been 81 at that time. His appearance
is that Of SMOOTH self satisfied man OF 40.
who has husbanded his health, and with whom the
world in general has thrven. He is said to be fond
Of the relaxation and quiet Of domestic life, and
that he does not make an empty boast when he says
that he has ratherfled from than been the pursner d
Office 1t would not probably be easy to estimate
how much he owes of the character he has for dis
interestedness and integrity to his tendency Of his
feelings and habits. He is Indifferent to office pro
bably because he is careful of his health. is font
OF his wife, or is rich, or has poor relations t.
provide for, or has got great deal OF station and
some fame by accident, and does not wish to hazard
the loss of any portion of them in official squad
bes or from any other cause equally defectable to
self. Probably his predictions to be traced to
success more strongly marking the magnanlmlty oil
his character but be this as it may, it is shrewdy
supected that, with the colleagues he had. he never
would have been able to introduce the little in
novatlon he has attempted in the criminal laws. q
he was not ready at all times to say, that he did moi
want office, and that he would be thankful to be c
,eved from its solicitude. There is certainly some
thng very imposing in an apparent contempt of au
thorlty and pef in contention for which, the worle
as kept in such agitation aud turmoil. Would tina
all public men shared in the sentiment, or could
successfully affect to do so ! | could lay my hnge
upon one great man who, by the mere show Of til,
dlslnterestedness of which the entire Peel family ar,
so boasted, could, in all human Likelihood, on NOR
occasions than one. have given freedom to a who'll
A q "a
pacity, it is, think, manltestly on the decline il
the House. Fortune intended high destiny 70
him-nature very humble one. Probably the iickl
goddess has now abandoned him to his own energe
and these, as think is already evident cannot, al
ter the lapse of very little time, keep him abov
the level of the fourth or fifth class even OF the mer
debaters Ne,0 York Times.

full articles.headline: FROM GREECE
full articles.article:
by vessel arrived at this port from NIarseilles,
we have received ii series of letters from Greece,
from Gen. Jarvis and DR.. Howe. We have not yet
had leisure TO peruse them all ; but that from the
laergentleman is Of deep interest, and gives Wv
I'D description Of the present state Of that distracted
country. The following postscript is dated Poros,
July 18th.


"P. s. The ship Six Brothers arriving at Ma
poll from New York, thought it my duty to advise
her rot 10 remain, as trouble was brewing and |
came here in her. This moment letters from Ma
poll inform that open war has broken out in the
place between Gryas, commander OF the upper cas-
IT,, anil Fontoumaris, commanding the lower. Gri-
vas is bombarding the place men, women and
children are killed and wounded every hour and
the English commander lying there has been obliged
to threaten in order to save the remaining families
the houses and shops are puudered a horrd
scene of confusion is going on-I go there in day
or two, to try TO remove the Hospital, and shall
write you.'' NJ Y. Com. .adv

full articles.headline: DE WITT CLINTON.
full articles.article:
Quick woRK.-We understand that the letter
from Jackson to Owens, in which be ISLANDERS the
living and the dead, was sent BY express from Ten
nessee to Owens in kentucky-who sentit by ex.
press to printer hundred miles distant. 1t was
then printed in handbs, and circulated by ex-
press. Although dated the 25th of July, and first
printed nigh 200 mile. from Robertson's Springs,
where it was written. it was sent to every County
in the state--at any rate to every Congressional
Dstrct--before the election. which commenced the
first Monday in August Quere-Who paid the ex.
peuse Ovens is notoriously bankrupt.


jackson wrote another electoneering letter to II.
Daniel, which was used in his stump speeches.
We should like To see that letter also printed
Every thing Old Hickory writes ought to go down
to posteri,y. AS they say in Tennessee, he ha'
ne1er placed lis name in block and ghae, that 1t de-
not elcuote him IN The eyes Of has cosonrymn.v Vide
Nashville Republican, Sept a. The letter to Da
mel of course i. splendid production, for it no
only elevated the Generals but his correspondent
too 1t elected him to Congress BY all means lie
us have the letter if sent to US in manuscript W.
will do our best to correct the orthography and syn
tax.-Kentucky Reporter.

Mrs. Hemana, the celebrated poetcss. having
been invited by the proprietors of the Philadelphia
Ladies Album, to take charge of that periodical
publication, with salary Of fifteen hundred dollars
per annum, has returned the following answer:
..RHi DON, ST. AsApii, 14th Aug. 1897.


" Sif,---l heg to acknowledge with thanks the ia

your Of your very oblisns letter. and request you to
inform your American friend, that am gratefully
sensible Of the compliment paid me by the offer you
have transmitted, but that the prospects 1T holds
forth, however tlattering, would not counterbaance
the Inconvenience attendant on leaving my own
country.


81 am, sir, your obliged servant,


SigneL FELICIA IlEMANS."

The following proclamation removing Eli Bruce,
the sheriff of Niagara county, has been issued by
Governor Clinton Mr.. Bruce was one OF the per-
sons concerned in the abduction of Morgan This
exercise of power on the part of the Governor will
be commended by every one


BY DE WI1TJLLV1ONG Governor Of The Stale Of


Ne,c- FORK.


Whereas Eli Bruce, sheriff of the county of Mia
CARA. has been charged before with violation u
his duties good citizen, and faithful officer, in
being concerned in the abduction of William Nor
gan, and has been heard in his defence: And where
as, in the investigation Of the said accusation, it ap
peared thatit was completely in the power Of the
And whereas, order to afford him that opportunity,
decision on the complaint has been suspended for
an ample time, and he has given no explanation OF
his conduct: And whereas it appears that at re-
cent trial at Canandaigua of certain persons charged
with the said abduction, the said Eli Bruce, when
called OH witness, refused to testify several
material points, OH the ground Of determination ;
from all of which, am persuaded that he was par
tcipant in the said abduction, and thereby has rem
dered himself unworthy Of the official station which
he at present occupies do therefore, pursuant to
the powers vested in me by the constitution of this
state remove the said Eli Bruce from the office Of
sheriff Of the county of Niagara
In witness whereof | have hereunto set my
H.. s. hand and the privy seal of the state, at the
city OF Albany, this 26Ih day of September,
Ammo Dumini, 1927.

full articles.headline:
Extract Of letter from gentleman IN Rio Jansiro,


dated 23d Of JNlu. 1927.
full articles.article:
Extract o leffer from gentleman n RIO Janslro,


doted a3d Of July, 1927.


"Ihe Buenos Ayres privateers come almost to
the mouth Of the harbour, and make many captures.
When within days sail of this port, the brig Leo
pard, of New York, for st. GATHERINGS bound here,
was brought to by pryateer and a Brazilian
gentleman passenger taken from her the privateer
formerly belonged to Baltimore, and was then call
ed the Beauty" Four or five days since, one O
these daring fellows hailed French frigate, anc
obtaining rather rough answer Immediately haul
ed athwart her (the irigate's) stern, and poured .
full broad side of grapesho into her wounded the
Commodore in the leg, besides killing two or three
men. have been informed that since his arrival
the commodore has had his leg amputated."

full articles.headline: From the National Intelkgencey.
full articles.article:
We understand that letters have been received
from General ATKINSON, dated on the Cd of Sepem.
ber. The General had with five hundred men. as
cended eighty miles up the Ouiscensin, on his way
to the Portage, and had been joined the preceding
evening by General DoDGE, with one hundred and
thirty Galena volunteers, mounted men. AT the
Portage, General ATKINSON would be met by Ma.
ior WHISTLER, with the detachment from Green
Bay, and would then hay collected force of one
thousand men, ready to move aa circumstances di.
rect. No hostile Indians had been met with, and
the General, at the date of his last letter. was still Of
opinion that the Wnnebagoes would give up the Of.
tenders agreeably to the demand which had been
made upon them.


A runor had reached BeIeville, in Illinois, thas
an attack had been made by the Indians upon the
settlers at the Lead Mines on Fever river, but by
the direct accounts which we have from ST. Louis,
to the 9Th ultimo, it proves to be entirely unfound
led


On Tuesday last. an address was delivered before
the Wing and Cliosophical societies of Princeton
College, in the presence of the faculty the trustees,
land large assemblage of citizens, by Theodore
Frelinshuysen, Esq. Attorney General of New.
Jersey.


| The veteran Commodore John Rodgers has been
appointed Commissioner Of the Navy. The Board
ls now mplete-consisting of Commodore Rodgers,


President, and Commodores Tin.ey and Warning


ton.


On Wednesday last, was the annual commence.


ment of the college at Princeton. n. J. vast
crowd Of citizens and strangers assembled, among


whom was Samuel l.. Southard Esq, Secretary Of


the U. S. Navy. who is now on a visit to his frends


in this state. The performances were highly crcti.
table to chose concerned.
